document:
Introduction
Systems should be periodically assessed for vulnerabilities.
Methods include vulnerability scanning, penetration testing, and auditing.
Tools can identify network weaknesses.
Security procedures help create a more secure computing environment.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Basics of Assessing a System – The Six Ps
Patch – Keep system patches up to date
Ports – Disable unneeded ports
Protect – Implement firewalls and intrusion detection systems
Policies – Enforce security policies
Probe – Regularly scan networks for flaws
Physical – Secure hardware and physical access

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Securing Computer Systems
Use established guides and templates:
- NSA Cybersecurity Publications
- Center for Internet Security (CIS)
- SANS Institute
Templates available for Windows via Microsoft documentation.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Securing Workstations and Servers
Workstations:
- Apply patches
- Restrict user privileges
- Use antivirus and firewalls
- Enforce password policies
Servers:
- Apply same rules as workstations
- Enable logging and review regularly
- Perform backups and disable unnecessary services

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Securing Networks
Secure all computers in the network.
Use firewalls, proxy servers, and IDS.
Segment networks using routers and firewalls.
Separate web servers from internal systems.
Consider a DMZ setup with inner and outer firewalls.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Demilitarized Zone (DMZ)
An area between internal and external networks.
Typically involves two firewalls:
- Outer firewall filters external traffic.
- Inner firewall protects the internal LAN.
Used to host web or email servers safely.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Network Scanning
Regularly check networks for vulnerabilities.
Popular tools:
- NESSUS (network vulnerabilities)
- OWASP Zap (web applications)
- Shodan (internet-exposed devices)
- Kali Linux (penetration testing toolkit)
- Vega and OpenVAS (open-source scanners)

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Testing and Scanning Standards
- NIST 800-115: Testing and Assessment Guide
- NSA-IAM: Penetration Test Standards
- PCI DSS: Credit card industry standard
- National Vulnerability Database (NVD): Public vulnerability repository using SCAP protocol

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Hiring Security Professionals
Certification: CNE, MCITP, CISSP, Security+, CASP, GAIC, Cisco
Education: Computer science or information systems
Experience: Minimum 5 years IT, 2 years security
Background: References, credit, and criminal record checks

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Summary
Regularly assess systems for vulnerabilities.
High-security sites: weekly; lower-risk sites: quarterly.
Secure networks, systems, and servers.
Apply best practices consistently across infrastructure.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Digital Forensics – Objectives
Understand forensic principles.
Create drive copies.
Use forensic tools.
Prepare reports.
Avoid procedural mistakes.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Introduction to Digital Forensics
Network admins are often first responders to cyber incidents.
Proper evidence handling is crucial for court admissibility.
Computer forensics focuses on scientifically extracting digital evidence.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
General Guidelines
- Do not touch suspect drives.
- Use Linux commands or forensic imaging tools (FTK Imager, OSForensics).
- Always create a forensic copy rather than analyzing live data.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Documentation and Chain of Custody
- Record all actions and personnel involved.
- Secure and restrict evidence access.
- Maintain a chain of custody log for all handling events.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
FBI Forensics Guidelines
Include cost documentation: labor, hardware damage, lost data, downtime, lost revenue.
Examples of evidence: logs, portable storage, emails, cell phones, and other digital devices.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
U.S. Secret Service Guidelines
Secure the scene.
Preserve evidence.
Establish legal basis before seizure.
Avoid file access and take photos.
Disconnect power if data destruction is suspected.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Digital Forensics Standards
SWGDE, ASCLD, RFC 3227, ISO/IEC 27037–27050 standards define collection, handling, and analysis of evidence.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Forensic Reporting and Tools
Reports must include: qualifications, actions, reasoning, and conclusions.
Common forensic tools: FTK, EnCase, OSForensics, Magnet Forensics, Sleuth Kit, Cellebrite.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Finding Evidence on a PC
Browsers can contain direct or indirect evidence.
Windows stores data in index.dat.
Tools can recover browsing history even if deleted.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Finding Evidence in Logs
Windows Logs: Security, Application, System, ForwardedEvents.
Linux: syslog, auth.log, messages.
System logs reveal unauthorized access or activities.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Recovering Deleted Files
Tools: FTK, OSForensics, EnCase, DiskDigger.
Deleted data can often be restored unless securely wiped.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Operating System Utilities
Windows tools: net sessions, openfiles, fc, netstat.
Useful for tracking network and file activity during investigations.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
The Windows Registry
Central configuration database.
Key hives: HKCR, HKCU, HKLM, HKU, HKCC.
Valuable forensic source using regedit.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Mobile Forensics – Cell Phone Concepts
Document phone state (factory, active, semi-active).
Identify SIM, IMSI, ICCID, and IMEI numbers.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Mobile Forensics – Network Aspects
Cell towers: antenna + radio base stations.
Cellular networks: GSM, EDGE, UMTS, LTE, 5G, iDEN.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Forensic Certifications
Certifications demonstrate minimum competence.
Examples: AccessData (FTK), EnCase, CHFI, GCFA, GCFE.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Expert Witnesses
Can provide opinion testimony under Federal Rule 702.
Daubert Standard ensures scientific validity of expert testimony in court.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Other Forensic Disciplines
Network forensics: capture and analyze packets using Wireshark, CommView, ngrep.
Virtual forensics: analyze virtualized environments and cloud resources.

metadata.file_name: Module 3 - Defense Architectures and Design - Part 1.pptx

document:
Summary
Always work on forensic copies.
Document every action.
Retrieve browser and deleted data.
Leverage registry and cloud information for evidence.
